Text: A Shiggaion of David, which he sang to the LORD concerning Cush, a Benjamite.
Context: An introduction providing context, identifying the type of psalm (Shiggaion), the author (David), and the circumstance (concerning Cush, a Benjamite).

Text: O LORD my God, I take refuge in You; save me and deliver me from all my pursuers,
Context: David appeals to God for protection, expressing a sense of being pursued or threatened.

Text: or they will tear me like a lion and rip me to pieces with no one to rescue me.
Context: An expression of fear, illustrating the peril David feels through vivid, violent imagery.

Text: O LORD my God, if I have done this, if there is injustice on my hands,
Context: David begins a self-examination, questioning before God if he has committed the wrong he is accused of.

Text: if I have rewarded my ally with evil, if I have plundered my foe without cause,
Context: David continues his reflection, considering actions that would be morally wrong, and unjust.

Text: then let my enemy pursue me and overtake me; let him trample my life to the ground and lay my honor in the dust. Selah
Context: A prayer for karmic justice if he is guilty, suggesting David is willing to suffer if he has indeed done wrong.

Text: Arise, O LORD, in Your anger; rise up against the fury of my enemies. Awake, my God; decree justice.
Context: David calls for God to intervene with righteous anger and to bring justice against his enemies.

Text: Let the assembled peoples gather around You; take Your seat over them on high.
Context: David appeals to God as the ultimate judge, envisioning a congregation witnessing God’s judgement.

Text: The LORD judges the peoples; vindicate me, O LORD, according to my righteousness and integrity.
Context: David expresses his trust in the LORD‘s judgement and asks to be judged by his own righteousness and integrity.

Text: Let the evil of the wicked come to an end, but establish the righteous, for it is You who examines the minds and hearts, O righteous God.
Context: David prays for God to put an end to wickedness and to vindicate the righteous, acknowledging God’s insight into inner thoughts and intentions.

Text: My shield is with God, who saves the upright in heart.
Context: David declares his trust in God as his protector, characterising himself as upright in heart.

Text: God is a righteous judge and a God who feels indignation every day.
Context: David affirms God‘s nature as a just judge who is not indifferent to evil.

Text: If one does not repent, He will sharpen His sword; He has bent His bow and made it ready.
Context: The verse warns of God’s preparedness to judge, implicitly instructing the need for repentance.

Text: He has prepared His deadly weapons; He ordains His arrows with flames.
Context: The language used here further emphasizes the severity of God‘s judgment upon the wicked.

Text: Behold, the wicked man is pregnant with evil, he conceives trouble and gives birth to deceit.
Context: David uses metaphorical language to depict the nature of the wicked as inherently deceptive and evil.

Text: He has dug a pit and hollowed it out; he has fallen into the hole he has made.
Context: The imagery extends to the consequences of evil actions, suggesting that the wicked ultimately entrap themselves.

Text: His trouble recoils on himself, and his violence falls on his own head.
Context: The principle of retribution is at work here, where the harm intended by the wicked is turned back on themselves.

Text: I will thank the LORD for His righteousness; I will sing the praises of the name of the LORD Most High.
Context: A conclusion of praise, where David commits to thanking and worshipping the LORD for His just and righteous nature.
